citations.narrative:
On 3/20/25, zoo staff identified early that morning that North American river otters, "Ophelia" (8 year old female) and
"Louie" (11 year old male) escaped from their outdoor enclosure and exhibit overnight during a winter snowstorm. Staff
determined via tracks and visual observation that both otters escaped through a small hole where the buried horizontal
fencing meets the vertical exhibit fencing in the area where the pond overflows. According to zoo personnel, the
attachment point had been exposed by erosion due to water flow and a wire tie had rusted, allowing a space that the
otters could access and enlarge.
The facility implemented their contingency plan, and "Ophelia" was successfully captured on 3/28/25, just outside the zoo,
in the hired trapper's trap. Her identity was confirmed via microchip and she was examined by the attending veterinarian
and determined to be in good health. At the time of this inspection, "Louie" has not been recovered. Zoo staff continues to
watch trail cameras and review information received from the public in hopes of his safe return.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals. A failure in this could lead to injury or escape from the facility. Escaped
animals have the potential for increased stress, discomfort, developing health issues, or being killed. Correct by ensuring
that all housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals and prevent future
escape.
***To be corrected from this day, May 9, 2025, going forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On 3/20/25, zoo staff identified early that morning that North American river otters, "Ophelia" (8 year old female) and 
"Louie" (11 year old male) escaped from their outdoor enclosure and exhibit overnight during a winter snowstorm. Staff 
determined via tracks and visual observation that both otters escaped through a small hole where the buried horizontal 
fencing meets the vertical exhibit fencing in the area where the pond overflows. According to zoo personnel, the 
attachment point had been exposed by erosion due to water flow and a wire tie had rusted, allowing a space that the 
otters could access and enlarge.  
 
The facility implemented their contingency plan, and "Ophelia" was successfully captured on 3/28/25, just outside the zoo, 
in the hired trapper's trap. Her identity was confirmed via microchip and she was examined by the attending veterinarian 
and determined to be in good health. At the time of this inspection, "Louie" has not been recovered. Zoo staff continues to 
watch trail cameras and review information received from the public in hopes of his safe return.  
 
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. A failure in this could lead to injury or escape from the facility. Escaped 
animals have the potential for increased stress, discomfort, developing health issues, or being killed. Correct by ensuring 
that all housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals and prevent future 
escape.  
 
***To be corrected from this day, May 9, 2025, going forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
